3224.content:
If you like Dynasty Warriors and Persona you enjoy the game. I'd give this title a 3.5 out of 5 being honest. It's like the best of both worlds but it does everything slightly worse. Example:

Persona 5: Confidants, city activities, new game plus upon completion of the title. 
Persona 5 Strikers: No confidants (replaced by team friendship or whatever its called), all of the previous confidants are gone on vacation in the city and you will never see them. New Game Plus is only unlocked after 100% the game.....which removes the purpose behind the new game plus. I'm not going to play through again for 1 persona.

Dynasty Warriors: Large Uninterrupted battles
Persona 5 Strikers: Have to enter battles the persona way by ripping off the opponents masks then attacking. 

Nice addition/subtraction: The negotiation system is gone. While I eventually got good at it in 5/R, the minigame was kinda pointless. Just collecting a persona via battling is a welcomed changed.

Good: Can enter/exit dungeons without day constraints. It doesnt pass time. There isn't much to do outside of missions anyways but hey at least they removed this as well. 

Combat system is fun. It's not a straight up ripoff of Dynasty warriors and all of the characters feel unique. 

Story is meh, predictable, and kinda wears out its welcome. For the first time ever playing a persona series I found myself wanting the game to end. I always loved the story telling between P4G, P3P, and P5/R. When you take away the great story, complex palaces now replaced by really large prisons, and confidants, the game doesn't feel the same. 

I was pleased with amount of Persona available and some actually have unique moves. Would I recommend full price? Nope. But do I regret my purchase? No. 

This game's sweet point would be about 40 bucks for someone who's a die hard fan of Persona. I also almost forgot, the performance on this game is wonky. Sometimes it's amazing then sometimes things just break and I just don't get it. I've occasionally seen the shadow on the table of your vehicle doing weird things that snatch your attention. I was in the city and it turned black multiple times and I couldn't see anything. And frame rate randomly drops. I have a 3090 playing between 1080p and 1440p.

3225.content: Honestly I liked this game way more than regular Persona 5. It felt more meaningful and less just take out the bad guy to change their heart. The characters felt so much more alive and the new characters were so loveable. Gameplay was the by far the best in the series and the jails had such fun creative designs. The soundtrack is incredible, the story felt more impactful and it got me so hooked ever since the 4th jail. The ending was beautiful and the graphics were just stunning at times. It makes me so happy to see how far persona has come and it is by far my favorite game series. This game is worth the 60 dollars completely. I wouldn't even hesitate  to play it again.  I really hope Persona continues to grow as a series and reach more people as it really is special.

3226.content:
A direct sequel to the incredible Persona 5. The main star is an awesome action combat system that is extremely faithful to the trademark Persona JRPG combat mechanics. Every single character is very different and a lot of fun to play. It's so good that I'd be happy if every Persona game going forward had it. A bunch of jamming new songs from Lyn, and returning remixed favorites as well. A lot of quality-of-life changes to fusion. The new characters are interesting, likable, and have good character arcs. It's also a much more manageable ~40 hours than the ~100+ of P5.

The story is a little fanfictiony, which is somewhat expected in Persona spin-off games. You'd better like Japanese food, because the game basically revolves around how awesome it is. The main departure from Persona 5 is the lack of a "time economy" (aka limited days) and the lack of social links.

It's pretty mandatory to have played Persona 5 (either version, references to Royal are basically non-existent); it will spoil large parts of the plot (if you care about that sort of thing), but more importantly, you'd have a hard time caring about the characters without the 100+ hours of context from P5.

3228.content:
Boy howdy, these Musou Games are getting pretty sophisticated. This game starts about four months after the end of the last game and continues most of the mechanics with some caveats. The day-to-day life simulator is watered down (and made infinitely easier) by just allowing you to pop out of dungeons for a breather and quick restock without losing anything. There are a couple exceptions to this, but nothing that sets the rule.

Combat is still triggered through bumping into shadow surrogates, like the last game, be it by getting the jump on them, them jumping you, or just smacking them and starting proper. Instead of teleporting to a battle dimension, enemies spawn in the world and you fight them like any other Musou. Of note, summoning your Persona or aiming your gun will cause the game to pause while you make your selections, which is nice. There are environmental objects to use to your advantage in addition to the set of skills you've come to know from the base game.

The story may be the weakest aspect of the game as it's mostly rehashing the same plot as the original game: deadly sins, rejection of cruelty, villains as dark reflections, teenagers using the power of love to kill God. You know the drill. The dialogue is characteristically ham-fisted - which I love - but can turn away the uninitiated. Also, if you were waiting for Ryuji to finally just say that F-Word, you'll get it at some point. I promise.

I'm not quite at the end as of this review, but I estimate the full game takes about 50-60 hours to complete depending on how side-quest happy you tend to be.

Shorter playthrough compared to P5 or P5R but still an awesome story. Music is the best and the gameplay is even fun for someone not into these kinds of action roleplaying games. 

Only downside is that during my playthrough ive had serveral crashes where the game just shutdown. That made sure that I saved at every chance that I got. 

Anyway I would very much recommend this game.

3232.content:
Story: Cute characters doing cute things.
[list]
    [*]Super predictable, would've benefited from more subtlety.
    [*]The big bads have TRAUMA, so you need to feel bad for them.
    [*]Lots of cute scenes.
[/list]

Combat: SUPER EXPLOITABLE, just don't play it like a warriors game or you'll get destroyed.
[list]
    [*]In 99% of situations, if you aren't spamming phys skills or exploiting weaknesses, you're losing damage.
    [*]Very easy to stunlock and no-hit major boss encounters the first time through, even on Hard.
    [*]Buffs matter a ton.
    [*]Super easy to prepare for major encounters. SP items are everywhere. As hard as you make it.
[/list]

Miscellaneous:
[list]
    [*]If you have an AMD CPU, you're very likely going to crash. No crashes after 4th Jail with Intel.
    [*]Anti-aliasing is practically in-existent.
    [*]Cutscene to gameplay ratio isn't great. Expect lots of downtime.
    [*]Difficulty could've been turned up a bit.
[/list]

TL;DR The game's great, just don't expect an amazing story. No crashes at all on an Intel CPU even after beating the 4th Jail. The combat is so exploitable it's almost like it wasn't tested much, yet at the same time the freedom to do whatever is nice.

If you have an AMD CPU, save frequently, and maybe consider getting the game once it goes on a discount. If patches are released in the future, this could change.

I hope it's P5R or P3FES next, gotta complete my Persona Game collection on my Steam library.

3240.content:
As someone with 400+ hours in the original Persona 5 game, I can say without a doubt that this is a worthy spin-off. The game not being turn-based did scare me a bit and yes, it is very difficult in the first 5 or so hours but after a while I got used to it and when you learn to mix combos and weaknesses it gets really fun to play (the teammates are also super fun to use; Yusuke, Haru and Wolf especially), Jails (basically dimestore Palaces) are very creative and beautiful to look at, the boss fights are incredible and I honestly liked the boss fights in Strikers more than than original P5. The fanservice was done very well, and the music is fantastic as usual (Axe to Grind and What You Wish For blows Last Surprise and Take Over out of the water). The new characters - Sophia and Zenkichi are both phenomenal additions with sick Persona designs and I found both of them to be complex and riveting (and also in the case of Sophia, the most adorable character of All Time). Also runs very well except for 2 crashes. 

I do have some gripes but they're mostly minor. The biggest complaint is that it's not entirely stable - I've crashed twice in the game for no reason. Bond points are tedious and if you want to max everything you have to get to bond level 99 which is asinine. The lock-on system is truly horrendous as well.

While it may be questionable whether it's worth 60 dollars, it is overall a fantastic spin-off which proves that while Atlus might milk the franchise, they're at least putting effort into it. I recommend this game especially if you loved P4G and P5/P5R. 

And of course, I, like everyone else, look forward to the inevitable Persona 3 and Persona 5 Royal PC port.

3243.content:
This is more than the average Persona spin-off. It is a true sequel to Persona 5 (not royal, basegame P5) as it keeps the superb character writing of the original while not falling to the general "Persona spinoff character archetypes".
The gameplay might be drastically different to the usual turn-based combat that the series is known for, but they've managed to make a great sequel that has such a different feeling.
I will say though, the final few chapters of the story fall back on basically repeating story arcs from P5 but with minor twists. The game is aware of this somewhat, and it does come up as a joke that this is incredibly similar to what the thieves has already experienced.

If you like Persona 5 in any way, I would strongly recommend this game, just remember to save often as the game tends to crash on me randomly

3244.content:
It's good. It's damn good.

This is not a dynasty warriors - style offshoot, a la the fire emblem or zelda warriors games; this is a true, blue sequel.

Story wise, it kinda rehashes the themes of the third semester in P5R, but that's not a bad thing. Some things are better touched on, and some things are less approached. It's a different look at the ideas. In addition, there's a lot of something both P5 and P5R were lacking: team building. The crew hangs out a lot. I mean, A LOT. there's good elaboration of character dynamics, a lot of humor, and it leaves you feeling warm inside the way well written characters do.

The new characters are well written and enjoyable (much more so than Kasumi, in my opinion). They find their place fairly quickly and latch on to you the way the others did in their own time.

Gameplay wise, it's dynasty warriors with some twists. A lot of components of traditional persona combat are integrated, but moved to a reaction based real time style- think of it as the changes from Dragon Age: Origins to DA2, but better. (in my opinion, much better). Strengths, weaknesses, technicals, baton passes and showtimes- they're here.

The soundtrack is, as expected of the persona franchise, fulla bangers. Look foreword to it.

I was glad to hang out with these weird kids in japan again, and I was not disappointed.

3245.content: A great blend of the Warriors series hack and slash mass combat and the Shin Megami Tensei / Persona combat mechanics.

3247.content: it's a fun Dynasty wars crossover that's not like the others out there. However I will say I do miss the social links and going on dates and what not with that. Strikers is a lot more combat oriented than hanging out with the homies oriented. Still though it's a fun game and if you want to see the crew back in action this is where to go. Although this takes place after P5 and has no association with P5 royal.

3249.content:
A fun muso game with a familiar cast and world with the same staples Persona 5 is known for such as it's great sound track and its style is also faithful. Combat is enjoyable and the way combos expand the more you play as each character is a good way to get you playing everyone and seeing each thief's arsenal while in combat. I really liked seeing the existing cast interact more in what felt like a more natural way. With new cast members thrown into the mix, it only strengthens the character line up within Persona 5's world. Certain characters however do end up boiling down to their singular trope such as Futaba being more egregious or Makoto doubling down on her motherly role within the group. 

Overall story was interesting enough to keep me wanted to see how it would progress. However, there were a few moments that felt repetitive in the game play when it came down to locations. Some areas feel copy/paste of one another which is a bit of a let down considering what potential could have been met.

The main negative however that I'd consider the real reason behind whether this game is worth getting on Steam is that it crashes. Not just once or twice but multiple times. Personally, it crashed 15+ times but some friends have had it crash much more or much less. It is not a great port over onto PC and with these issues being so irregular, be prepared to what you could end up dealing with.

3250.content: You definitely have to play persona 5 first before playing this (not royal). Besides that, its such an amazing blend of the warriors genre with persona 5 gameplay. One of my favorite games of the year at the moment.

3264.content:
I genuinely really like this game. It's significantly better than other Warriors styled games I've played in the past (though BOTW: Age of Calamity was just as good as this game, I'd say) and it manages to retain Persona 5's style really well despite being so different gameplay-wise. Once you get the hang of it, the battle mechanics of this game feel really fluid and satisfying to pull off, and while these types of games are known for being spammy, I think with the amount of variety between each playable character and the varied settings you encounter, the game does a really good job with not becoming stale. I think that the character interactions are fun and that the plot progression was more well developed than I was expecting out of a Warriors-type spin off. It really felt like I was playing Persona 5 and the only thing that was different was how I hit things.
The reason I'm currently not recommending this game (a reason I'm gladly willing to change my recommendation for if fixed in the future) is because it crashes and softlocks itself far often. I've made an obsessive habit of saving after literally every small action I take because every time this game has to load something in, there's an unnecessarily high possibility of it crashing. At the time of this review, I have about 35 hours in this game (end of the 5th jail) and I was having a really good time with it, until I reached a point after a boss fight where loading in from the metaverse softlocks the game. I know it hasn't crashed because the game still responds if the controller is disconnected, but I'm otherwise met with a black screen I cannot hope to progress from. From the research I did into this issue, it seems my computer isn't the only one softlocking at that exact point in the game.
I implore Atlus/ Koei-Tecmo to patch the game so that the PC port is actually functional, because I think it's a real shame they let this great game be released while this broken.

3267.content:
Picks up right where Persona 5 left off, which as a returning player from the original Persona 5 feels great. The game will probably make less sense for people who aren't familiar with the original Persona 5, but the gameplay is still solid regardless. 

There are a lot of QoL changes made in Strikers that just weren't there in the original Persona 5, some to accommodate the new Dynasty-Warriors type combat, while others are just generally nice changes (such as no punishment for returning to the real world from the Metaverse). 

Overall if you've played the original Persona 5 and don't mind the switchup in the core combat loop, I highly recommend this game. If you haven't played the original Persona 5, you can still enjoy this game for what it's worth but you may miss out on references made to the original game.

3273.content:
[h1] ▬▬ 🆃🅰🅺🅴 🆈🅾🆄🆁 🅷🅴🅰🆁🆃 ▬▬ [/h1]

[hr][/hr]

The Phantom Thieves are back in this new action-packed sequel to the [b]original[/b] Persona 5 game. [spoiler] Meaning Kasumi does not exist in this game, Atlus please add her as a DLC later maybe. :) [/spoiler] With a new threat posing the world, the thieves are reunited together to kick some more ass.

[b]Persona 5: Strikers[/b] introduces a new hack-and-slash combat system to give the series a fresh take. As Atlus always delivers, there is also incredible UI transitions, music compositions, and stories to explore in the world. By buying the Deluxe Edition, you will be granted access to the digital interactive artbook, soundtrack, and some behind-the-scenes making of Striker's music- on top of that, you will also receive some bonuses in-game to aid you in your battles.

[spoiler] SPOILER ALERTS: Do NOT peek at the artbook until you're finished with the game, the artbook contains spoilers. The opening cinematic to the game also contains a tiny portion of spoilers, in case you're wondering about that. [/spoiler]

This game will have you traveling across several cities and towns based in Japan. You will meet new faces, discover hidden treasures, find an abundance of different shops to buy a variety of items from, and clear "Jails" (which are pretty much a twisted variation of the old "Palaces", you will find out more about them in the game).

All-in-all, if you are looking to expand your knowledge of the Persona universe, or you just want to beat up a bunch of shadows and bosses, this game is likely for you. 

[hr][/hr]

Below are my own opinions about the game after clearing through the game and having 100+ hours of experience. Currently on my way to 100%-ing the game's achievements. Whether you agree or disagree to my opinion(s) is all entirely up to you. I have a bias towards the Persona series, but I will try my best to be truthfully honest about this game.

[h2] NEGATIVES ABOUT THE GAME [/h2]
While this game is overall really good, I can't say this game goes without having a few issues that comes with it straight out of the box. I'll get the negatives out of the way first.

[list]
[*] My biggest complaint are the random, constant game crashes as well as the infinite loading screens. No matter what you try to do, it seems you can't do anything to fix them. Playing full-screen or windowed-borderless mode causes them more frequently, so I usually play on windowed-mode. You can also try lowering the graphics, but I doubt that'd help. My only tip is to SAVE OFTEN- YOU WILL CRASH. Until they send out a patch to fix these crashes, save often because there is no autosave. I've lost a few hours of progress due to this, the same goes to my friend who's had more crashing issues than me.

[*] Keyboard controls and assisted-aiming feels really clunky. I've played on both keyboard and gamepad, the controls still feel somewhat clunky but once you adjust it should feel fine. The target assistance in the game feels really off, Sometimes I want to ambush a certain enemy, but it ambushes an entirely different enemy. Or even when I want to lock onto a rail to ride on it, I end up doing something completely different.

[*] The anti-aliasing option seems... odd? Not sure how to describe it, but I just left it as it is. Some people might have a problem with it depending on your graphics card.

[*] The DLCs aren't really worth buying separately. You can easily grind the content you get from the DLC. Either buy the Deluxe edition and don't look back, or buy the regular game and play it as it is. Trust me, you'll be fine either way.
[/list]

[h2] POSITIVES ABOUT THE GAME [/h2]
Finally, the positives about the game. There really is a large amount of positives I want to point out from the game, but I'll try to tl;dr it.

[list]
[*] The storyline is how you expect it to be from a Persona game. You'll be going along for a roller-coaster ride of plot twists, fun and sad moments. You'll easily get attached to some new characters as well. While the gameplay experience isn't as long or sophisticated as the original Persona 5 game, you will still get a nice feeling of satisfaction after clearing the story.

[*] As I mentioned earlier, Atlus feeds us yet another game full of art-beloved UI transitions and new musical compositions. If you love Persona for what it is, you'll love this game. Expect to be jamming to Persona music for a while.

[*] While the battle system has changed into a hack-and-slash style from the original turn-based system, I can say for certain that this is a completely new breath of fresh air. Even by saying it's just a hack-and-slash is not fair to this game, there's much more to it that you'll explore. I actually prefer this over the original combat system. It's just full of constant action and doesn't feel boring at all.

[*] END GAME CONTENT- MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD: While there is no clear end-game story, additional content comes in the form of New Game+; essentially you can start a new game with all of your stats carrying over to the new game. You can also opt in to try out Merciless mode, the hardest difficulty of Strikers there is. Once you start Merciless mode, you can't back out. There is also some content you can only unlock in New Game+, so you'll have to play through the game at least twice to unlock all the achievements if you're looking to do that. It feels really nice beating bosses at maximum difficulty.

[*] Each Jail is unique- unlike Palaces from previous games. Every jail you visit will feel fresh, as they're designed to be a new experience from other jails. Each one will have its own atmosphere and aesthetic. Play the game for yourself to find out how different Jails are from Palaces.

[*] You are able to switch between the Phantom Thieves and play as Makoto, Haru, Ann- hell even Morgana. Each thief has their own playstyle. Mix and match your party and find out which strategy works for you! (note: you can't play as Futaba, she's a support character for obvious reasons yet again)

[*] Flashy all-out attacks and showtimes are still present. You will feel like a bad-ass performing these while Last Surprise plays in the background.

[*] PERSONA ON PC!?!?!?!?!? One step closer to Persona becoming the norm for PC gaming.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2] GAME RATINGS [/h2]

Controls: 6 / 10 - 7 / 10 if you're on controller
Gameplay: 8.5 / 10
Storyline: 10 / 10
Music: 11 / 10
Waifus: too powerful to rate

bought the game 3 times for pc + switch, as well for a friend. worth.

[h2] CONCLUSION [/h2]
[hr][/hr]

[i]tl;dr[/i] [b] game good, but please add royal to steam, I have too much free time.[/b]

That concludes my review of Persona 5: Strikers. Good luck out there, fellow thieves-

3279.content:
After eight hours of play I experienced my first crash. This reset *roughly* twenty minutes of dialogue / cutscenes but I figured this was a good time to detail my first impressions.

Everything from here on can contain a spoiler, read the TL;DR if you want.

If you have experience with FF: XIII or Kingdom Hearts, you'll feel right at home. The majority of the combat is face-paced, hack'n'slash gameplay that feels enjoyably intense. While not up to Devil May Cry levels of complexity, the fights are very fun. Team member selection is vital to not getting teamwiped, even at the early levels, typical for an Atlus game.

I think this game was designed for a controller in mind, if you have one: play with it. Otherwise, I highly recommend rebinding almost every default combat / interaction key in the game. While initially frustrating, like most games on PC, a good keybinding setup is the first skill in any game. 

If you're new to the genre or Atlus games, don't be afraid to play on easy. I don't claim to be an expert to these type of games but, as a very competitive individual, I did get sent back to the loading screen more than once before completing the first dungeon on normal. Don't expect to be a god at this game if you have limited to no experience w/ the combat of other Atlus games. As is usual of this brand: the skill ceiling is high, the floor is rock bottom. And, trust me, the game is trying to make you experience rock bottom.

As for sound, top notch. The music has caused me, more than once, to sit back in my chair and take my hands of the controls. Some tracks are nostalgic from P5; others completely new. Each it's own an experience worth noting. The voice acting is solid. It really helps engross you in the story that would, otherwise, be boring to read.

Graphics are what I expected: anime. The cutscenes are well done w/ a mix of 2D and 3D animation. I want to make a note: I am not a fan of 3D modeling / animation BUT it's done well. The combat feels fun and looks great.

TL;DR

Sound: 10/10 - The soundtrack is amazing, voice acting engrossing
Graphics: 9/10 - I don't have a problem w/ 60fps and graphics that come straight from PS4. Feels Persona 5, man.
Gameplay: 9/10 - High learning curve. Can be very punishing but rewards good strategy. Initial keybindings are T R A S H.

I experienced my first game crash an hour before writing this review. This game has bugs.
Regardless, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone that enjoys strategic, fast-paced hack'n'slash games.

Edit: 34 hours and still playing. Suffered another crash that reset me the final 1/3 of a dungeon. Another 30 minute setback; nothing major. Frustrating, but both of my game crashes occurred after extended sessions (6+ hours). Rereading my initial impressions: all of them still have merit. My gut tells me I'm entering the final stages of the story. I'll give my final thoughts when I finish.

3291.content:
This game is a must buy for people who have played the original or the Royal version of Persona 5 (or at least in cases have watched a playthrough). The story is as funny and emotional as ever and there are improvements on almost every level; The music is great, the characters still keep their development from the last game, the UI somehow tops the original, and the combat is very fun and addicting. I would suggest this game for everybody but the characters often refrence moments and characters from the original game and don't explain complex things over again like the metaverse or Morgana.

This section is to grade how worth it the digital deluxe edition is:
The digital deluxe edition is hard to say the quality off. In order to access the content you need to push the Play button specifically in Steam for the game and it will ask whether you want to play the game or the 'app'. The quality of the app is very sketchy as right from the start it has a Unity watermark at the beginning. It gives you a Digital Art Book, A Behind the Scenes Video, and a Soundtrack Player:

Digital Art Book:
The digital art book was disappointing to me. It is nice to see the artwork and some concept art here and there it doesn't have any writing from the artists about what they were trying to do or the challenges they had to face in making it. This is the worst part of the package.

Behind the Scenes Video:
The behind the scenes video is pretty much a non narrated documentary that shows how Lyn and Lotus Juice made the opening song "You Are Stronger". It mostly focuses on the difficulties of having a non native speaker sing english and it really shows how they are masters of their craft, so much so to where Lyn was able to find out that the reason her singing sound off was because the mic was just 2 inches too low, which is very impressive to me. I'd say if you like Behind the Scenes and Filmmakers commentaries you'll like this, however it should be really easy to find it on youtube.

Soundtrack Player:
The soundtrack player is ok. It just feels like a standard music player with a Persona Skin layered over it. The main thing that sucks about it is that you can only listen to the tracks in this player and have to have it open in order to listen to them, no downloads. You're better off just finding the soundtrack on youtube.

The main reason for wanting to spend $10 extra dollars though would be to have the music play in game. You get some in game items that you won't care about but when you get this edition you get the battle themes of every main line persona game!... except for Persona 5 and Royal... from what I heard you have to have save data from those games in order to get those tracks... which means only Playstation players can get them. However, it is really cool hearing music like, Mass Destruction or Reach Out to the Truth play when you start combat, it even has music from Persona 1 as well which I do not know the name of but really like. If you like these tracks than its only 10 bucks and you get to pick which tracks you dont want to here and in each battle they will randomize which track you get.

Now, when I finished it on hard and started my merciless run I can write this rewiew
My Exp in Persona games consists of P4G, P5 and P5R
So, lets go to the diff, pros and contras

First and the most is new combat system. It's not turnbased. Check it before buying game, and if u dont dislike it just give this game a try. It's really nice!

There is no itemize, but you dont really want to have skill cards, until its passive skill

Here you fuse them,you can up their stats, but all this is just to don't suck at power level and have personas default drains/nulls.
I cant say that its minus, cos now fights are a little more about your dodges and combos, not about 1st turn hassou tobi. It's still about debilitate/Matarukaja+Masukukaja+Marakukaja, but now it's diffirent. Just give it a try

+++++++++++++++

3303.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a brilliant action RPG sequel to Persona 5, it's turn based original. The story, even though it's not at the level of the prequel in my opinion, continues to expand the Persona universe and shows how much effort has been put into the development phase of this game.

There are currently a few bugs that break immersion, such as occasional game crashing, average loading times and being able to challenge the Monarch of Sapporo without sending a calling card, but nothing ridiculously game breaking that makes the game unplayable.

All in all, a perfect sequel to a perfect franchise and I can't recommend this game enough to Persona fans. All we need now is for Atlus to release Persona 5/Royal on Steam for us PC players to enjoy even more!

3310.content:
Didn't finish the story yet, but so far I am really enjoying the game.

I love the art style, the music and let's not forget the level design. The fact that there aren't to many games today that do this is a shame.

As far as gameplay goes, I really enjoy both turn based and warrior type games, so the switch in style is no problem for me (sad to see the game get some hate on account of this). From my point of view, the way they incorporated Persona 5 mechanics into this game is well done. Even tho there is button mashing involved, I often find myself looking at it from a strategical point of view (which character should I use, what enemy should go down first, what buffs/debuffs to use, should I use SP move or combo etc)

Regarding the story, at this point in time I can't say much, but so far it meets my expectations. I do miss some aspects that have no been included, mostly secondary character stories (as Persona 5 does have some nice characters), but I wouldn't say it's a deal breaker.

I did experience some crashes, however in my 30h of gameplay, this only happened twice, none of which have been in crucial moments like boss fights, or even jail exploring, so I can't say I've been bothered that much (would still be nice to get these patched tho).

While exploring you will see objects popping in and out of existence, but usually it's small stuff, like rocks and to be honest, most of the time I hardly notice them (since I'm usually looking out for enemies, chests, junk and so on).

Despite the flaws mentioned above, I still think it's a great game and would recommend it to any fan of the series and hope that sometime in the future, we will be able to enjoy Persona 5 Royal as well. ^^

3318.content:
A very solid game, if you're a fan of Persona 5. The game has a good narrative, that adds fun and good new characters to the universe. I would say that the story is a bit cliche but its follows the standard Persona narrative. If you have played a Persona game you most likely will know where the story is heading.

I had some issues tho, the game continues Persona 5's annoying group dialogue, the group hardly gets to talk about their life's or enjoy the time and instead most of the dialogue is spent talking about the Phantom Thieves instead of something more interesting or funny. This was an issue in the last game and continues to be an issue with this game. Atlus also for some reason chooses to end the group events really quickly. I was very annoyed when this happened since it happened alot during 5, THIS GAME IS ALL ABOUT HANGING OUT WITH THE GROUP AND THEY END IT SO FAST. sorry, but these choices is what makes 5's group a lot more worse than 4's and 3's since the group feels more like the Phantom Thieves instead of a friend group that you can relate to. But if you were fine with it in 5 you will feel the same way about it in this game. 

There is also a lack of optional story content. Most of the optional content is done through requests, that let you go back to previous places to do different challenges to unlock things. All the characters have their own mini side request for you, and all it does is give more dialogue. I felt that this was a huge misfire, i understand not adding a huge side portion of the game, but at least give us a scene or two with these characters by ourselves, to further explore them. They have ONE scene where you get an option to pick one of the characters to go on a trip with you, that's it. Side content is one of the best parts of Persona games and with so little here it makes me a little disappointed.

Combat is very fun. It is also very engaging with many different characters that open different ways to play. The only issue is that certain parts of the game are not very challenging on hard.  Again, with Persona games most of the boss battles are hit or miss, they rely on similar gimmicks to defeat them. Once you learn this gimmicks most boss battles will be finished in the first try. Combat is really fun, like i said, but it seems that because they added so many things to help your character, they really made the game less difficult in the process. 

Again, Atlus does an amazing job with the visuals. The ui in this game is better than the last game, adding flashy things to the ui makes going into a menu much more cooler. The many different places you will visit on your roadtrip are very cool looking. They do a good job capturing the different looks of Japan, from the country side too how different the cities look in the different provinces. The music is also amazing, most tracks return from 5 but the battle music, the backround music, and the remixes of 5's tracks really add alot to the game.


I had a few issues with the port. Most of my issues were with crashes during loading, for some reason i had none when in combat. Very annoying since it does not allow you to save whenever you want. 


Even with my issues with the narrative and other parts of the game, P5 Strikers is still a great experience that i think every Persona fan should play.

3320.content:
Strikers serves as a good sequel to Persona 5. It's not perfect by any means, but it's good. It continues the story of the Phantom Thieves and takes you on a fun adventure with the thieves again. The road trip concept is really fun and you get a lot of interaction between them, though the writing doesn't feel as solid as vanilla P5 or Royal did.

As someone who's had minimum experience with the warrior series, playing Strikers was easy to get into. However, I would recommend turning off the automatic camera as soon as you can, as it made me confused playing. Also pay close attention to enemy weaknesses and abuse that as much as possible while getting combos and All Out Attacks.

Early game, try and grind out money as much as you can, upgrading the bond that raises money gain and bond exp asap. It gets easier as the game goes on but I find myself running out of money quite often if you wanna gear up your entire team at once.

Being able to pause the game to use Persona skills or items is very nice and allows you to think about your next move.

The game does feel lackluster in some areas though, most notably in dungeon length and some story elements. Some dungeons are longer than others, while a few are only floor long. They don't spend a whole lot of time on some characters or moments either and some characters feel one dimensional. But if you're just looking for a good time and wanna smash some buttons and are a fan of the Phantom Thieves, I would recommend it.

3321.content:
The game is great.

Bring P5R to Steam. 

Obligatory fuck Epic Games.

3323.content: Finally Joker from Super Smash Bros. Ultimate has his own game

3324.content:
I was a bit worried at first that this game wouldn't live up to Persona 5, and well, I shouldn't have been. This game is fun. It's a lot of fun. The combat is so much fun, it's fun to go looking for it instead of avoiding the JRPG vanilla Persona 5 which gets tiring after 100 battles of grinding. It also doesn't take itself too seriously, I mean, you can ride a skateboard and run over shadows with it. You get to do realtime combat with all-out attacks, follow-ups, one-mores, technicals, persona skills/swapping, baton-passes, etc etc. It's a blast to play. I HIGHLY implore you play the game on Hard for your first run. This game NAILS hard mode so well. Unlike other games that make their higher difficulties bullshit and unfair, this game makes it fair. Not only are the enemies tougher, but so are you. You do more damage as well. Combined with dodging and countering, it makes for a super fun combat experience.

The story is pretty damn good so far too. It feels like a proper sequel to Persona 5, though any part of the game like the base game does feel a bit more empty / simplified. Keep in mind that this game is a sequel to the vanilla Persona 5, NOT ROYAL. All the characters are the same as ever and enjoyable to watch and interact with. While Confidants/Social-Links are not present, you still get to bond with your friends a good amount not only in combat but in the real-world through events; reminiscent of Persona 4.

The biggest complaint you'll probably hear from this game are the bugs. The game has this weird tendency to crash whenever you leave/enter the Metaverse. I'm unsure why. You can luckily save a lot in this game, especially right before you load a new area so it shouldn't be that much of a hindrance as long as you save. The game also has a 60fps cap and some poor Anti-Aliasing which I hope will be fixed with a patch. It's not enough to make the experience any less enjoyable, I just hope it's fixed soon because it may be more buggy depending on the hardware.

Overall, very fun game. Definitely worth the price. It's around 50 hours I've seen from other playthroughs. Not too far off from the length of Persona 4. There's a good amount of fan-service here. I highly would not recommend this game if you haven't played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal yet, as you probably won't have as much of an emotional connection with the characters / plot as you would with. The DLCs aren't very worth it in my opinion, unless you get them from the Deluxe version. The All-Out Attack Pack seems to be relatively worthless, while the Legacy BGM Pack is a bit pricey and only worth it if you're a big Persona fan. (Or just like Mass Destruction)

3331.content:
First of all. [h1] Hoooooo boy [/h1] Props to Omega-Force/Koei Tecmo, and P-Studio for making this game happened, and to Atlus for publishing this game to steam (praise be to Atlus). I will gladly buy any MegaTen related games.

Okay so, I'll make this as concise as possible.
The story (although a direct continuation from the base game) is basically a reimagine of Persona 5's with a bunch of changes specifically for this spin-off. I'm just gonna say it follows the same structure, that's it (for those who have played, you'll know what I mean). It actually reminds me of the movie called HER because of how the plot heavily uses artificial intelligence as its main topic. Expect a lot of dialogue since this is still a persona game.

The gameplay is good no doubt about that, actually great. Who knew that a game that uses the combination between musou combat with persona mechanics would actually work wonders, I never thought it would be this good. Each character you control has different combat style and special ability. It's really the highlight of this spin-off.

Probably the complains I have are the price and possibly, the end game content (I have my doubts on this one though) since when you finish the game, the only replayability value that this game will give you after finishing it are new game+ (you can totally 100% achievement in the 2nd playthrough) and a new difficulty. I really hope Atlus will update this game with new content, although it's unlikely to happen because this game was released in Japan a year ago and (to my knowledge) there had been no update since then.

All in all it's a good game, as expected of Atlus. Even though they really milk this series hard, you can bet the spin offs of each game are done and polished really friggin well. A definite must have for those who enjoy both persona and musou combat type of games.

3332.content:
Still playing through the game, however, I must say this is an incredible fusion of Persona 5's excellent style and Warriors.

I think it's DNA is more P5 than it is Warriors but that REALLY works in its favor.

Unfortunately, this game would leave someone who hasn't played P5 rather confused a lot of the time I feel. If you have played it though, this game is a very intriguing new story that takes place afterwards. It's awesome to have the gang back together for another adventure!

3335.content: Great "DLC" for Persona 5 main game. I bought this with the hope that Atlus will bring Persona 3 FES and Persona 5 Royal to PC.

3336.content:
*IMPORTANT* 
This game crashes ALOT, at the worst time possible. I'm not sure why; to make things worse, the checkpoints to save the game are quite far in between so uhh, the anxiety of hoping the game won't crash while you're far away from a save point is stressful. So if you're playing, remember to save as many times as possible. Redoing what you did from the past 3 hours is not fun. 

Anyways, Persona 5 Strikers is a nice sequel for fans of Persona 5 (Royal). However, the combat is a musou-type game, being completely different from Persona 5's turn based combat. Although, it is very interesting to see how they incorporated hack and slash with the tactical use of personas & baton passes.

The overworld exploration is satisfying, being able to walk around Shibuya, Sapporo, Osaka, and so on with your pals is a nice feeling. 

One thing to note is how the new Velvet Room functions. With the removal of social links, you can't get bonus exp for your personas from social links. Instead you can level up your personas through the use of PPs (Persona Points) which is a little disappointing but it's fine.

To further explain on the removal of social links, Persona 5 Strikers introduces a mechanic called Bonds to replace it. With bonds, you may unlock certain bonus perks like "Extra Money Dropped Per Battle" & so on. You can get bond points from playing through the game.

It's a game to play if you're interested to see what's up with the Phantom Friends after the first game. Not so for the depth of the combat/gameplay, Persona 5 (Royal) still triumphs on that part. 

Some mechanics from the first game were revamped or changed to be better/worse. It's up to you to make your own opinion on it.
